Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Habitability of Antarctic Lakes and Detectability of Microbial Life in Icy Environments by Aautonomous Year-round Instrumentation
Award.AbstractNarration:
EAGER: Collaborative Research: Habitability of Antarctic lakes and detectability of microbial life in icy environments by autonomous year-round instrumentation, is supported by the Antarctic Integrated System Science (AISS) and the Antarctic Organisms and Ecosystems (AOE) programs within the Antarctic Sciences section in the Division of Polar Programs within the Geosciences Directorate of the National Sciences Foundation (NSF). The funds will allow the measurement of year-round properties of the microbes and the surrounding water in Lake Bonney, a lake with four meters of permanent ice cover over forty meters of liquid water in the Dry Valleys of Antarctica. NSF funds will be used to support the deployment, and the science enabled by the deployment, and NASA (the National Aeronautics and Space Administration) funds will be used to purchase the equipment.

Intellectual Merit: This research will be the first to make year-round measurements of the microbial community, and several associated environmental variables, in the continuously liquid portions of Lake Bonney, Antarctica. Three different types of equipment will be deployed in each of the lobes of Lake Bonney. The first instrument is an ITP (an ice-tethered profiler) that will measure physical parameters such as temperature, dissolved oxygen, and chlorophyll throughout the full depth of the liquid water portion of the lake, making measurements at least once each week. The second and third instruments will be used to collect discrete water samples at least every two weeks to determine A) the biological community (assessing metabolic and phylogenetic diversity) and B) the geochemistry (e.g., dissolved organic carbon, and dissolved inorganic nitrogen species). Such samplers have never been used to measure these properties year-round in the Antarctic. Cold temperatures, bottom lake water salinities that are four times greater than the ocean, the thick permanent ice cover, and the lack of sunlight to recharge batteries all present significant challenges for the project, thus classifying the work as an early, high-risk, high-reward activity (the acronym EAGER stands for Early-concept Grants for Exploratory Research).

Broader Impacts: There is much interest in understanding the ecosystems of the Polar regions in an era of climate change. Logistical limitations dictate much of this work only take place in the summer, until new autonomous technologies can open the door for year-round measurements. This award will be the first to attempt year-round microbial sampling in Antarctica. The McMurdo Dry Valleys region is also the site of a Long-Term Ecological Research (LTER) Program, and the research conducted on this project with benefit from, and contribute to, the larger LTER project. The instruments used in the project will be purchased by NASA, so two separate agencies have agreed to explore the feasibility of an early stage project. There will be at least three graduate student trained during the project, and the team will also participate in outreach activities at several venues including the Crow Reservation in Montana.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Knowledge of the McMurdo Dry Valley lake ecosystems is limited by inaccessibility of the region during winter, a period that is highly relevant to understanding the biogeochemistry of these lakes. We conducted the first year-round investigation of the biogeophysics of these unique lakes using a suite of in-situ instruments. Autonomous Lake Profilers and Samplers (ALPS) were assembled and deployed at the primary productivity maxima of the east (ELB) and west (WLB) lobes of Lake Bonney in December 2013. Initial data were retrieved in November 2014 and  the systems were redeployed in January 2015. The instruments consisted of: (i) a Phytoplankton Sampler (PPS) for phytoplankton genetic diversity; (ii) a Remote Access Sampler (RAS) for organic carbon and nitrogen determination as well as dissolved organic carbon and ion composition: and (iii) a modified ice tethered profiler (ITP) containing a CTD, photometer and an in-situ spectrofluorometer (BBE Fluroprobe) designed to quantify chlorophyll-a from in four distinct algal classes.

We used this instrumentation to test the overarching hypothesis that winter darkness induces a cascade of physiological changes that alters the biodiversity and functional roles of autotrophic and heterotrophic microplankton within the lakes.

The Montana State University component of this study focused on describing changes in total algal biomass (chlorophyll-a) and changes in the four main classes of phytoplankton in the lakes over a selected depth range representing the deep summer phytoplankton production maxima. The Fluoroprobe measures total chlorophyll-a fluorescence following emission of assessory pigments specific to green algae, cyanobacteria, cryptophytes and a mixed group dominated by chrysophytes.

Under-ice irradiance at 15 m was undetectable in ELB between May and late August, a period where total chlorophyll-a declined (Figure 1). The decline in total chlorophyll reflected the decrease in green algae during this period. Of interest is the increase in the mixed group during the polar night. Genetic sequence data revealed that this group consist of a number of groups capable of injesting bacteria to fulfill their metabolic demands without light. The mixed group began to decline in late winter possibly from viral or fungal attacks, which are common in monospecific systems. Chlorophyll-a in all groups began to increase with the onset of light in autumn.

Phytoplankton Shannon diversity in ELB and WLB decreased noticably during the winter (Figure 2), reflecting the dominance of the mixotrophic chrysophytes and decrease in the other three algal groups. Phytoplankton  diversity increased in autumn with the onset of light in ELB, a trend not evident in WLB phytoplankton diversity.

Our results are the first to show the dynamical changes in phytoplankton that occur during the polar night in lakes of the McMurdo Dry Valleys. These data, in concert with genomic and biogeochemical data (still being processed), will provide us with important new information on ecosystem changes during winter that will allow us to understand processes during the ensuing summer season.
